intro: Collomia gracilis var. humilior, commonly known as the dwarf Indian paintbrush, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, which includes many parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant is characterized by its vibrant red or orange floral bracts that resemble paintbrushes, which are used to attract pollinators. It typically grows in open, disturbed habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. The species is known for its delicate, low-growing habit and its ability to thrive in poor soil conditions.
